The Farewell

This week I was all over the shop mentally. On Friday I had to just bed down in work with headphones on, but all-in-all itâ€™s been another good week. We lost a good member of the team, but the weeknotes community has proven itself incredible yet again. Happy to say that we even managed to attract someone new to the crew!

Four Things ThatÂ Happened

More than four things happened

One

Monday and Tuesday were filled with the introduction and basic training days for user research for government services. Though Iâ€™m no stranger to the practice (and have written about what happens when you donâ€™t do user research), I wanted to see if the context of working in government changed anything.

It turns out it doesnâ€™t, not by much. User research is such a robust, worthy field of work that you will reap the rewards by taking time to listen to what people need. The core concept is to reduce wasted effort and time by building the right thing, what people need not what they want. The only difference with user research in government is that you canâ€™t be selective with your user personas: this is for everyone. In the private sector your personas focus around people whoâ€™ll drive your revenue, but not so in government.

My only criticism of the course is that I donâ€™t feel enough time was spent on eliminating bias. During the activities and practice sessions, the research questions were tainted by bias â€“ designed to validate assumptions rather than invalidate, leading one to an expected answer â€“ and user stories ended up being solutionistic. Itâ€™s no fault of the course leaders, they had lots to cover for an audience relatively new to a complex field, but Iâ€™ll pass on the feedback. Bias is one of the more difficult topics, but this article on cognitive biases that affect decisions is gold-dust.

Someone also told the story of how theyâ€™d seen several teams conduct research after delivering a project, as a checkbox exercise to get past the Service Standard. Itâ€™s appalling behaviour and will come back to bite them, as it did me.
